utterances: Many have been upset and really this has provoked a lot of anxiety in many patients.
Bachelor says things aren't always as bad as they used to be for patients like Kennedy.
He goes to his computer and punches up a scan from another of his patients.
Like Kennedy, Janice Durham was also diagnosed with a malignant glioma.
So what we're looking at here is one of the initial scans that Janice had when she came under our care.
It shows a golf-ball-sized glioma in the frontal lobe of her brain.
Durham remembers the day when she had her first scan.
She could hardly absorb the news.
They came out and they were ashen-faced and said that I had a mass in my brain and I needed to find a neurosurgeon.
And the next day I was supposed to do a stress management workshop and get the oil changed in my van.
So I sort of said, OK, I've got to get the oil changed in the van, do a stress management workshop and find a neurosurgeon.
As it happened, Durham canceled that workshop and didn't get the oil changed.
Unlike Kennedy, she didn't have surgery.
Doctors said her glioma was too wrapped around vital brain structures for surgeons to operate.
Durham's husband, Steven Suddick(ph), says the message they got was as gloomy as it could be.
One of the doctors that we talked with at Mass General said there is no hope, there is no hope.
Everybody dies of this.
But what else could she do?
With two adolescents at home, Durham embarked on the treatment course that is similar to the one that Kennedy will probably get.
But unlike Durham, the Senator will probably get radiation and chemotherapy at the same time, instead of one after another.
Recent evidence suggests that prolongs survival.
Durham's response to radiation and chemotherapy was spectacular.
After a year's treatment, she and her husband went to Bachelor to hear the results of her latest MRI scan.
He came in and he said that the MRI looked good.
And we said so what - like how big is it?
What's left?
And he said, well, there's nothing left.
And we said, well, what do you mean there's nothing left?
And he said, well, it's all dead tissue.
There's no active tumor anymore.
So we were just sort of stunned, completely stunned.
Janice Durham is now doing fine five years after she got malignant glioma.
She has one big advantage over Kennedy.
She was 50 when she got her diagnosis, 26 years younger than Kennedy is.
Even so, experts say it's impossible to know if Kennedy will be among those who outlive the usual expectations.
Richard Knox, NPR News, Boston.

Bennis, let me start with you.

This is one of those trips that in many people's minds put the secretary in a quandary, no right, no wrong.
How much is being run from the State Department?
How much is truly being run from the White House?
I think it's very difficult to know exactly where that fine line is drawn.
We know that Condoleezza Rice is closer to President Bush certainly than her predecessor, Colin Powell.
There was a picture, a very vivid picture of her on the front page of The New York Times this morning looking visibly upset and angry in her public statement in Rome.
But I think, at the end of the day, she is the public face of this policy.
And whether she privately disagrees with it or not is profoundly irrelevant given the damage that this policy is doing in the Middle East and globally in terms of how the U.S.
is viewed around the world and what its policies are doing to the world.

So I think that if she actually does disagree with this policy, if it's being run by Cheney and the neo-cons against he advice of the realists on the other side, if you will, she has an obligation to resign and protest.
Without that, it's profoundly irrelevant historically whether she has any private disagreements or not, just as it was with Colin Powell.
How much is the perception - because as you say, we don't know for sure that she is in lockstep with almost everything this president says.
How much does that truly hurt her status?
I think, ironically, it helps her status as a viable agent of U.S.
policy.
There can certainly be no question raised about Condoleezza Rice as there was about Colin Powell.
Does he really speak for this president?
I don't think anyone doubts that.
So when she speaks, she speaks with great authority because of that longstanding personal relationship that George Bush has gone out of his way to promote.
Having said that, it means that the impact of this policy is far more important in terms of how people perceive our entire country.
And unfortunately, our entire people are held accountable for this policy because it is seen as representing the essence of what the U.S.
policy is.

Felix, let me turn my attention to you and ask you the idea of here is a woman that is truly seen as a Renaissance woman.
She has varied interests.
And yet on the other end, she has a very hard line when it comes to the idea of being a woman taken seriously in a, quote, man's world.
How much has this been a problem for her historically, and do you see that as problematic in her dealings today?

Well, since she has aligned herself with the Bush administration with working first on the Security Council for the first Bush president, George, Sr., she has made herself very comfortable within this particular group of leaders - as Phyllis described them, the neo-cons - who she has really been very much in close affiliation with as far as her policy outlook, the way that she has evolved her career as a policymaker.
So this hardline stance really follows so well with the others with whom she has made her career.
And I don't think that she has had to fight that sort of fight of being more of a dove or having a stance on all of these foreign policies that she now is actually claiming throughout the world.
She hasn't had to do that kind of fight because she hasn't had a very different type of outlook to try to defend within the White House or within this administration.

Do you think that she takes on the mantle of stepping up, being a trailblazer for women, and particularly in her position as Secretary of State, dealing with the men and nations that don't always take, quote, women seriously.
Do you think that she enjoys that?

Well, I think just by the very nature of her personality that's something that is automatically going to happen, because she has had experience in this through her first position of course with the Security Council, and then being the national security adviser for George W.
She has had to meet some very headstrong characters, of course, especially in the former Soviet Union, and she made quite a reputation for herself by being able to stand up to them.

I don't think that she has deliberately gone out and tried to prove in certain deliberate ways that, because she is a woman, she is able to still demand a lot of respect for her field and for her status in foreign policy.
I think that's just the way Condoleezza Rice is as a person.
She does not seem to be very dedicated to making some sort of statement about being a woman in her position.
It's always been what her policy is and what her position is.
And her personality has always been a very, very confident and not one to think that she has to defend her gender in order to apply it to what her status or what her power should be.
Ms.
Bennis, Condoleezza Rice has been fiercely loyal to not only this president, but their family working with, as you suggested earlier, her father.

peacekeepers are being slaughtered and saying it's not time for a cease-fire.

policy on a global level of doing exactly the same thing.

National Security Strategy document, which outlines a notion of a new world in which no nation or a group of nations could ever imagine that they might stand as equals, let alone challenge U.S.

is doing it at the global level, and those two policies fit together very, very well.
